topic.title: PHY <-> OTN CBR Mapping Datapaths

li.p: 10GE (1a), 25GE (1b), 50GE (1c), 200GE (1e), 400GE (1f) Ethernet client adapted for BMP mapping into OTN.
100GE Ethernet client adapted for GMP mapping into OTN (1d).

body.p: On the receive path, the different Ethernet clients (10GE, 25GE, 50GE, 100GE, 400GE) coming from the SERDES go through the PHY RX blocks that performs the PMA, FEC and PCS receive functions. Data then goes through the FEMP that performs mapping adaptation functions and is forwarded to the ECPB mapping buffer. Optional non-intrusive MAC PMON can be achieved by broadcasting the traffic toward the FEMP and RX MAC. Optional packet extraction can be achieved using the FEPP_I. For FlexE unaware mapping, optional FLEXE PMON can be achieved by broadcasting the traffic toward the FLEXE_DEMUX. The MAPOTN subsystem then retrieve the code words and MAP them into BMP for 10GE/25GE/50GE/400GE or GMP for 100GE. The BMP follows the client rate, while for GMP traffic is mapped with a client Cn. The client rate information is carried for each channel from the SERDES to the MAPOTN subsystem outside the ENET.

On the transmit path, the MAPOTN subsystem demaps the traffic from BMP for 10GE/25GE/50GE/400GE or from GMP for 100GE and stores the code words into the ECPB demapping buffer. Data then goes through the FEDP that performs demapping adaptation functions and is forwarded to the PHY TX block. The PHY TX block performs the PMA, FEC and PCS transmit functions. Optional non-intrusive PMON can be achieved by broadcasting the traffic toward the FEDP and TX MAC. Optional packet extraction can be achieved using the FEPP_E. The BMP follows the client rate, while the GMP is de-mapped with a client Cn. The client rate information is carried for each channel from the MAPOTN to the SERDES outside the ENET subsystem. The ENET listen to the SERDES rate to determine when traffic is transmitted.
